content.description:
Begin with some shifty moves to start with a big move to a side cling/rail.  After the side cling, shuffle up to the jugs. Watch Christian's vimeo video if you want the beta spray.

vimeo.com/65411646
content.protection: A bouldering pad is nice for the start. There is lots of elk turds/dust. Two pads might be nice on this one...the landing is a little sloped.
content.location: It is in the  middle of the main wall cliff directly underneath a bolt on the right hand side. This goes up a thinner/blank section of the cliff face compared to the stuff on the left. Look for the left, sloping, diagonal start hold.

content.description:
Start standing with both of your hands matched on a crescent-shaped edge at 4.5 feet. Traverse right via a series of powerful and techy moves on sidepulls and underclings until you're situated under a small overlap at 6.5 feet. Gain the undercling in the overlap above, and make a big move to gain a good edge at 11 feet. Match here, and call it good (you can continue up for another move or two to high jugs, but these are usually covered in guano, so I tend to avoid that finish). The good holds located to the right of the overlap are off (see the topo photo). Using these reduces the difficulty noticeably and removes one of the coolest moves on the climb, which is the big deadpoint to the high edge.

This is contrived, like most of the lines at Society, but an enjoyable and challenging line with some unique movement.
content.protection: A few pads are useful due to the traversing nature.
content.location: This problem starts on a crescent-shaped edge in the middle of The Main Wall.

content.description:
This is a fun eliminate and one of the harder problems on the cliff. Sit start five feet to the right of

Frosted Flake Sit

on a slanted, horizontal rail. Move up and left using crimps and slopers (the vertical crack up and right of the start is off), aiming for the chalked up jug above the seam. Finish on

Frosted Flake

, and drop off.

This is the uncontrived and easier version of

The Alien Traverse.

Start standing in the corner with your hands matched on an edge at 5.5 feet. This is the same start as for

Frosted Flakes

and

The Alien Traverse

. Traverse right on slopey jugs for 6 feet, and then pop up and right to a very large, incut jug. From here, angle rightwards to finish at a large pocket. This is the same finish as for

The Alien Traverse

.

This is a nice line that is perhaps a bit more fun than the contrived extension.
content.location: Located on the left side of The Main Wall, this starts beneath the obvious, overhanging flake.

content.description:
Start wherever you want.  End wherever you want.  Go high, go low, there are endless variations...the Society Turn crag seems made for traversing.  If you try to make it as long as possible, you end up traversing a LONG ways, and in some cases you might find yourself soloing, as a fall on some of the higher sections is unthinkable.  Even if you are climbing fast, the entire traverse up and back down can take 45 minutes to an hour.  It is possible to go all the way until the crag peters out entirely, before starting up again to form the higher cliffs above.  This description does not include the hard, chalked up section where the trail meets the crag, which would make it considerably harder, but is in a way out of character with the laid back nature of the rest of the traverse.

Oh yeah, make sure you avoid the guano, it's found all over the place, and is probably unsanitary if not unhealthy for a person.  But don't let that put you off, now!
content.protection: Nothing but your hands and feet.

content.description:
This is a long traverse that climbs through the hardest sections of The Main Wall. It's basically two V7ish sections separated by an easier middle section with rest potential. Personally, I feel that this climbs more like a route than a boulder problem, but a bouldering grade is more in line with the rest of Society Turn.

Start standing on the far left side as for

The Alien Traverse

. Climb

The Alien Traverse

rightwards, but when you get to the vertical seams, keep climbing rightwards (using holds at head height ) into the start of

The Undercling Traverse

. Finish as for that problem.

This is long and pumpy, though if you're good at recovering, you may get a lot of it back in the middle. It is easy to work.
content.protection: Many pads would be needed to protect the whole thing, so you may just have to place them wherever you think you might fall.
content.location: This problem starts on the far left side of The Main Wall and traverses almost the entire wall.

content.description:
Start standing on the boulder just to the left of where the trail hits Society Turn.  Look up at the jug above you (approximately 8-9 feet above the boulder).  Jump off the boulder and latch the jug.  Campus a few moves up and then mantle.  10-15 feet of moderate slab to the finish.

A fun, unique problem that I THINK was not done until Tristan and I hunted it down in the Fall of 2004.  Kind of ungradeable...
content.protection: None.  Not a good one to fall on.
content.location: Stand on the boulder located just left of the trailhead at Society Turn.  The problem goes straight up the cliffband above.  Descend with short downclimb to the left.

content.description:
This is the harder version of

Skip's Hard One

.

Start sitting with both hands matched on an incut slot at around 3 feet. Use a pair of crimps to gain a crimp sidepull and angle leftwards towards the large, incut jug. From the jug, move leftwards to gain the finish of

Frosted Flakes

. Drop off.

This climb is similar to

Skip's Hard One

except that it eliminates

ALL

of the good holds to the right of the start. This includes the juggy, vertical seams, the large horizontal shelf used for feet and the large incut edge hold as well (see the topo photo). This makes the moves significantly harder. Hard pulls on sloping crimps makes this a straightforward test of finger strength.

Though it may seem like this is an eliminate of an eliminate, I would argue that this is the purer, better line and a more straightforward contrivance than '

Skip's Hard One

'.
content.protection: A few pads are useful due to the traversing nature of the problem.
content.location: This is located on the left side of The Main Wall. Look for a low horizontal shelf. This problem starts just left of that.

content.description:
This is the sit start to

Frosted Flake

. It is down and right from original start. Start with left and right sideclings. climb to slopers, then move left and into

Frosted Flake

.
content.protection: A bouldering pad is nice for the start. There is lots of elk turds/dust.

content.description:
Climb

Frosted Flake

(sit start) into

The Alien Traverse

.

This is commonly done as a toprope but is also a fun, short, lead climb. If you are standing at the bottom of the main wall/overhang, this climb starts at the base of

Yara River Eliminate

boulder problem and climbs up to the one and only bolt (20-25 feet up). Clip the bolt and climb through a few sets of overhangs to a pumpy traverse out right. Plug in some gear in the big, horizontal traverse, and make a bouldery move to pull the last lip. This climbs one of the biggest lines on the cliff, 50 feet, 5.11+.
content.protection: 1 bolt halfway up, a #2 for the horizontal above, a few other options along the way.
content.location: This is on the middle/right hand side of the main wall at Society Turn. Look for the one and only bolt (has some faded tat on it), along with the overhanging roofs. There are a few variations in terms of the boulder problems you could do leading up to the bolt. If top roping, you'll need to extend your anchor quite a bit.

content.description: Start under the unmistakeable fin/flake on the right end of the cave.

Start the same as

Frosted Flake

, but traverse right along slopey seams at the top of the bulge. After hitting a good right hand sidepull, climb up to a guano-covered jug, and drop off.

Start on the boulder problem “

Frosted Flake

,” V2. Go up to a lonely bolt in the middle of the route, then place two cams in an horizontal, flared crack. Then pull on the roof - spicy leading. If the left side of the horizontal crack is bomber, then you can place other pretty solid cam, and it would be a PG-13 lead.
content.protection: 1 bolt + cams #2 and #3 to a bolted anchor.
content.location:
This is an extension of the problem

Frosted Flake

on the left side of the wall.
